paper_id: Optimizing rice yield, quality and nutrient use efficiency through combined application of nitrogen and potassium

paper_metadata.title: Optimizing rice yield, quality and nutrient use efficiency through combined application of nitrogen and potassium
paper_metadata.research_focus: Optimizing rice yield, quality, and nutrient use efficiency through combined application of nitrogen and potassium fertilizers.
paper_metadata.soil_k_relevance: Potassium (K) is an essential nutrient for rice growth and development, with its application rates significantly influencing K uptake, utilization efficiency, and interaction with nitrogen, ultimately affecting rice yield and quality. The study investigates soil K levels and its dynamics under various N and K fertilization regimes.

research_context.study_objectives: To explore the interactive effects of combined nitrogen (N) and potassium (K) application on rice nutrient absorption and utilization, yield, and quality. To clarify the optimal ratio of N and K conducive to achieving both high yield and high quality for the super indica hybrid rice cultivar Yixiangyou 2115. Additionally, to assess the molecular response of rice grains to different fertilizer application rates by quantifying expression levels of N and K metabolism-related key genes.
research_context.soil_k_research_role: Soil K is characterized as a baseline property of the experimental site. The study directly investigates the effects of varying K application rates (0, 90, 135, 180 kg ha⁻¹) on soil K dynamics, specifically K uptake by rice plants, K use efficiency, and its impact on overall rice performance, in combination with N fertilization.
research_context.geographic_setting: Research farm of Sichuan Agricultural University, Wenjiang city, Sichuan Province, China (30°70′ N, 103°83′ E).
research_context.environmental_conditions: Climate data during rice growth period: 2019 (daily average temperature 22.78 °C, daily average rainfall 3.69 mm); 2020 (daily average temperature 23.31 °C, daily average rainfall 6.53 mm).
research_context.agricultural_context: Rice (Oryza sativa L.) cultivation, specifically using the super indica hybrid rice cultivar Yixiangyou 2115. The field was continuously flooded with river water. Field management (pests and weeds) followed local cultural practices.
research_context.study_design: A two-year (2019 and 2020) field experiment using a two-factor factorial design with three levels of N (135, 180, and 225 kg ha⁻¹, denoted as N1, N2, and N3) and four levels of K (0, 90, 135, and 180 kg ha⁻¹, denoted as K0, K1, K2, and K3). The experiment was conducted using a randomized complete block design with three replicates, totaling 12 treatments. No nitrogen application treatment was established for yield calculation, but a zero-N/K plot was used for nutrient absorption/utilization calculations.
research_context.temporal_scope: Study duration: Two growing seasons (2019 and 2020). Sowing dates: April 12, 2019 and April 14, 2020. Transplanting dates: May 27, 2019 and May 26, 2020. Harvest dates: September 19, 2019 and September 20, 2020. Sampling for dry matter and nutrient accumulation: Full heading stage (August 9, 2019 and August 13, 2020) and maturity stage (September 14, 2019 and September 15, 2020).
research_context.spatial_scope: Each test plot had an area of 5.0 m × 5.0 m. Transplant density was 30 cm × 25 cm (row spacing × plant spacing) with one seedling per hill. Ridges with plastic film were used for separation, and protection lines were established between treatment blocks to ensure isolation.

concentration_measurements.measurement_method: Soil analysis (method not specified, but results reported)
concentration_measurements.sample_context: Topsoil layer (0-0.20 m) prior to experiment establishment

concentration_measurements.measurement_method: Soil analysis (method not specified, but results reported)
concentration_measurements.sample_context: Topsoil layer (0-0.20 m) prior to experiment establishment

concentration_measurements.measurement_method: Soil analysis (method not specified, but results reported)
concentration_measurements.sample_context: Topsoil layer (0-0.20 m) prior to experiment establishment

concentration_measurements.measurement_method: Soil analysis (method not specified, but results reported)
concentration_measurements.sample_context: Topsoil layer (0-0.20 m) prior to experiment establishment

pool_characterizations.pool_type: Total K accumulation in aboveground parts (stem-sheath, leaf, panicle)
pool_characterizations.analytical_method: Flame photometer (M-410, Sherwood Scientific Ltd., Cambridge, UK) after digestion with concentrated H₂SO₄ and H₂O₂
pool_characterizations.temporal_variation: Varied between 2019 and 2020. In 2019, maximum increases were obtained under N3K2 (176.30%). In 2020, maximum increases were obtained under N3K1 (88.21%).

treatment_effects.N3K2_2019: Maximum total K uptake (176.30% increase compared to other treatments)
treatment_effects.N3K1_2020: Maximum total K uptake (88.21% increase compared to other treatments)

balance_calculations.trend: Decreased with increasing K application at the same N level.
Increased within a certain range with K application at the same N level.

temporal_patterns.monitoring_frequency: Soil properties once prior to experiment; plant K uptake at full heading and maturity stages.

long_term_trends.trend_description: Varied between the two years, with inconsistent or not conspicuous changes for some indexes.

event_responses.soil_k_response: Increased K uptake and K use efficiency (KRE, KCR, KHI) within certain ranges, while KAE decreased.
event_responses.response_timing: Throughout growing season, measured at full heading and maturity stages.

cycling_processes.description: Plants acquire K directly via ion channels or transporters from the soil.

quantification.total_k_accumulation: Highest total K accumulation at maturity stage observed under N3K2 (2019) and N3K1 (2020).

cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Calculated as Plant K concentration × Plant DM weight.

cycling_processes.description: Movement of K from roots to shoots and into panicles.

quantification.KHI: K harvest index (KHI) increased with increasing N levels, indicating K translocation to panicles.

cycling_processes.measurement_approach: KHI calculated as K accumulation in panicle / Total K accumulation in aboveground parts.

plant_soil_interactions.description: K application promotes root development, which subsequently enhances nutrient uptake by plants. Combined N and K application can promote N and K uptake and accumulation in aboveground parts.

quantitative_data.total_k_uptake_increase_N3: Compared with N1, total K uptake under N3 at maturity stage increased by 17.68-40.99%.

plant_soil_interactions.temporal_patterns: Observed at full heading and maturity stages.

plant_soil_interactions.description: Expression levels of K metabolism-related genes (OsHAK1, OsHAK5, OsAKT1) in rice grains are influenced by N and K application rates.
plant_soil_interactions.temporal_patterns: Measured at mid-filling stage (15 days after flowering).

chemical_processes.characterization: The study measured 'Available K' in the topsoil layer, indicating the readily accessible pool of K for plant uptake.
chemical_processes.implications: Relatively high content of available K in the experimental field soil might have influenced the appearance quality of rice when additional K was applied.

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: Potassium fertilizer application rates (K0, K1, K2, K3)

soil_k_effects.K_uptake: Increased with appropriate K application, more obvious at high N levels.

experimental_treatments.effect_duration: Throughout the growing season, measured at full heading and maturity stages.
mechanisms: Enhancement of nutrient uptake by plants

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: Combined application of Nitrogen and Potassium

soil_k_effects.Total_K_accumulation: Highest total K accumulation at maturity stage under N3K2 (2019) and N3K1 (2020).
soil_k_effects.KRE: Maximum increases under N1K3 (193.30-236.86% in both years) and N3K1 (1664.63% in 2020).
soil_k_effects.KHI: Maximum increases under N3K0 (171.06% in 2019) and N3K1 (121.91% in 2020).
soil_k_effects.K_metabolism_gene_expression: Higher expression levels of OsHAK1, OsHAK5, and OsAKT1 in rice grains observed under N3K2 or N3K3.

mechanisms: Synergistic effects on nutrient absorption and utilization.

comparative_analysis.comparison_type: Different K application rates at same N level

soil_k_differences.KRE: Increased with K application within a certain range.
soil_k_differences.KCR: Increased with K application within a certain range.

comparative_analysis.statistical_significance: K had extremely significant interactive effects on recovery efficiency and harvest index of K (p < 0.01).
N had extremely significant interactive effects on KHI (p < 0.01).

analytical_methods.procedure_description: Dried plant samples were ground to powder, passed through a 0.20 mm sieve, and digested with a mixture of concentrated H₂SO₄ and H₂O₂. K concentration was then determined using a flame photometer.
analytical_methods.instrumentation: Flame photometer (M-410, Sherwood Scientific Ltd., Cambridge, UK)

analytical_methods.method_name: Soil property analysis (including Total K and Available K)
analytical_methods.procedure_description: Soil samples from the topsoil layer (0-0.20 m) were analyzed prior to the establishment of the field experiment. Specific analytical procedures for K were not detailed.
analytical_methods.instrumentation: Not specified for soil K analysis.

sampling_design.spatial_sampling: Soil samples from the topsoil layer (0-0.20 m) prior to experiment. Plant samples: Ten representative hills sampled from each plot (5.0 m x 5.0 m) based on average number of tillers.
sampling_design.temporal_sampling: Soil sampled once prior to experiment. Plant samples collected at full heading stage (Aug 9, 2019; Aug 13, 2020) and maturity stage (Sept 14, 2019; Sept 15, 2020).
sampling_design.sample_processing: Plant samples were separated into stem-sheath, leaf, and panicle parts, oven-dried at 105°C for 30 min and then to constant weight at 80°C. Dried samples were ground to powder and passed through a 0.20 mm sieve.
sampling_design.storage_handling: Not explicitly detailed for samples prior to analysis.
sampling_design.representativeness: Ten representative hills per plot aimed to capture average plant characteristics.

precision_measures: Standard deviations (mean ± standard deviation, n=3) are reported for all quantitative measurements in tables.
uncertainty_sources: Variations in N and K use efficiency indexes were inconsistent or not conspicuous between the two years, which might be related to the unique characteristics of the YXY 2115 cultivar or the relatively high content of available K in the experimental field soil.

climate_conditions.temperature: Daily average 22.78 °C (2019), 23.31 °C (2020) during rice growth period.
climate_conditions.precipitation: Daily average 3.69 mm (2019), 6.53 mm (2020) during rice growth period.

landscape_context.topography: Research farm, specific topography not detailed.
landscape_context.drainage: Continuously flooded with river water, implying controlled drainage.
landscape_context.position: Research farm of Sichuan Agricultural University, Wenjiang city, Sichuan Province, China.
landscape_context.land_use_history: Not detailed, but implies continuous rice cultivation.

research_integration.relationship_to_other_measurements: Soil K measurements and plant K uptake/utilization are directly linked to N application rates, dry matter accumulation, rice yield, and various rice quality indexes (milling, appearance, cooking, eating quality). Correlation analysis was performed between K-related indexes and yield/quality.
research_integration.integration_with_plant_studies: The study integrates soil K with plant physiological responses (dry matter accumulation, nutrient absorption) and molecular biology (expression of K metabolism-related genes like OsHAK1, OsHAK5, OsAKT1 in rice grains).
research_integration.connection_to_broader_objectives: The research aims to provide a theoretical basis for optimizing cultivation methods to achieve high yield, high quality, and reduced fertilizer input for rice production in southwest China, contributing to sustainable agricultural development.
research_integration.comparative_context: The study compares the effects of different N and K application rates, and their combined effects, on rice performance over two years. Findings are discussed in the context of existing literature on N and K fertilization in rice.
research_integration.literature_positioning: The study addresses the common problem of heavy N application and insufficient K application in Chinese rice production, aiming to provide systematic investigation into combined N and K effects, especially for the widely cultivated Yixiangyou 2115 cultivar.

spatial_limitations: Study conducted at a single research farm, limiting generalizability to broader spatial scales.
methodological_constraints: Specific analytical methods for soil Total K and Available K were not explicitly detailed.

Variations in N and K use efficiency indexes were inconsistent or not conspicuous across the two years, which might be related to the unique characteristics of the YXY 2115 cultivar or the relatively high content of available K in the experimental field soil.
interpretation_caveats: The observed decrease in rice appearance quality with increasing K application might be due to the relatively high available K content in the experimental field soil, differing from previous studies.
No significant differences or prominent impacts were found in the response of RVA profile characters to co-application of N and K, indicating limited effects on rice starch viscosity.

extraction_assessment.extraction_notes: Soil K analytical methods (for total and available K) were not explicitly detailed in the paper, only the results were provided in Table 1. All other requested soil K information, including quantitative data, temporal and spatial context, and methodological approaches, were extracted as reported by the researchers.
